<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>

(b) The 1D coordination motif of 1. The aromatic π-π stacking interactions are shown as green dashed lines. (c) View of the parallel stacking mode of the 1D arrays in 1. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.).

The aromatic π-π stacking interactions are shown as green dashed lines. <ce:section-title id="st105">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0050" view="all">
<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="o0005">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0095" view="all">Three diverse 1D coordination polymers are constructed from a versatile tripyridyltriazole ligand and Cd(II) halides.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="o0010">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0100" view="all">Different binding features of halide ions are observed to direct the structural assemblies.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="o0015">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0105" view="all">Solid state fluorescent emissions of the complexes can also be regulated.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ Three diverse 1D coordination polymers are constructed from a versatile tripyridyltriazole ligand and Cd(II) halides.   ⋅ Different binding features of halide ions are observed to direct the structural assemblies.   ⋅ Solid state fluorescent emissions of the complexes can also be regulated.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0095" view="all">Three diverse 1D coordination polymers are constructed from a versatile tripyridyltriazole ligand and Cd(II) halides.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0100" view="all">Different binding features of halide ions are observed to direct the structural assemblies.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0105" view="all">Solid state fluorescent emissions of the complexes can also be regulated.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st110">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Three distinct Cd(II) coordination polymers [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Cd(<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), and [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) have been designed and synthesized with a versatile building block 3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-4-(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>) by altering the Cd(II) halides of reaction systems. Single crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> display different zigzag, box-like, and ladder-like 1D polymeric motifs, respectively. Moreover, aromatic stacking interactions are observed in all these structures to extend and/or stabilize the supramolecular lattices. Their thermal stabilities and fluorescent properties have also been explored. Significantly, the regular variation in structural patterns and photoluminescence properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> can be properly ascribed to the diversification of halide anions.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Three diverse 1D coordination polymers are constructed from a versatile tripyridyltriazole ligand and Cd(II) halides.

Different binding features of halide ions are observed to direct the structural assemblies.

Solid state fluorescent emissions of the complexes can also be regulated.

Abstract

Three distinct Cd(II) coordination polymers [Cd3(L434 )2Cl6] n  (1), [Cd(L434 )2Br2] n  (2), and [Cd2(L434 )2I4(H2O)2] n  (3) have been designed and synthesized with a versatile building block 3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-4-(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (L434 ) by altering the Cd(II) halides of reaction systems. Single crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that 1-3 display different zigzag, box-like, and ladder-like 1D polymeric motifs, respectively. Moreover, aromatic stacking interactions are observed in all these structures to extend and/or stabilize the supramolecular lattices. Their thermal stabilities and fluorescent properties have also been explored. Significantly, the regular variation in structural patterns and photoluminescence properties of 1-3 can be properly ascribed to the diversification of halide anions.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st005">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Crystal engineering is of great significance since it can provide a rational strategy for creating multifarious crystalline materials, prearranged by the building blocks with appropriate structure-directing groups for intermolecular contacts, such as the most familiar coordination and H-bonding interactions . Coordination polymers, as an essential topic of crystal engineering, evoke increased interests in view of their fascinating structural features and promising applications as new crystalline materials . In general, the sophisticated strategy for constructing coordination polymers is largely dependent on the design of organic or inorganic building units with desired connected features. The organic tectons with suited functional groups and molecular skeletons have been demonstrated to be most critical to fine-tune the coordination motifs. On the other hand, elaborate selection of reaction parameters such as pH conditions , solvents , anions , and additives , may also well regulate the final products.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Crystal engineering is of great significance since it can provide a rational strategy for creating multifarious crystalline materials, prearranged by the building blocks with appropriate structure-directing groups for intermolecular contacts, such as the most familiar coordination and H-bonding interactions . Coordination polymers, as an essential topic of crystal engineering, evoke increased interests in view of their fascinating structural features and promising applications as new crystalline materials . In general, the sophisticated strategy for constructing coordination polymers is largely dependent on the design of organic or inorganic building units with desired connected features. The organic tectons with suited functional groups and molecular skeletons have been demonstrated to be most critical to fine-tune the coordination motifs. On the other hand, elaborate selection of reaction parameters such as pH conditions , solvents , anions , and additives , may also well regulate the final products.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">In this context, we select herein a novel tripyridyl-substituted 1,2,4-triazole building block 3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-4-(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>), with adaptable conformations and binding fashions as well as potential capability for participating in secondary aromatic stacking interactions, to assemble with different CdX<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> salts (X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cl, Br, and I). As a result, three different 1D coordination polymers, namely [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Cd(<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), and [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) can be obtained, which demonstrate the significant influence of halide anions on their structural assemblies. In addition, thermal stability and solid-state fluorescent emissions of these polymeric complexes have also been explored.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this context, we select herein a novel tripyridyl-substituted 1,2,4-triazole building block 3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-4-(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (L434 ), with adaptable conformations and binding fashions as well as potential capability for participating in secondary aromatic stacking interactions, to assemble with different CdX2 salts (X=Cl, Br, and I). As a result, three different 1D coordination polymers, namely [Cd3(L434 )2Cl6] n  (1), [Cd(L434 )2Br2] n  (2), and [Cd2(L434 )2I4(H2O)2] n  (3) can be obtained, which demonstrate the significant influence of halide anions on their structural assemblies. In addition, thermal stability and solid-state fluorescent emissions of these polymeric complexes have also been explored.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and general methods

All analytical grade chemicals and solvents were purchased and used as received. The ligand L434  was synthesized according to a comparable literature procedure . Fourier transform (FT) IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on an AVATAR-370 (Nicolet) spectrometer. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were taken on a CE-440 (Leemanlabs) analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis experiments were performed on a TGA Q500 thermal analyzer in 25-800°C (heating rate: 10°C/min) under N2 atmosphere with an empty Al2O3 crucible as the reference. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer at 40kV and 100mA for a Cu-target tube (λ =1.5406Å). The calculated PXRD patterns were obtained from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data by using PLATON (see ).

Synthesis and characterization

Typical syntheses of 1-3. The ligand L434  (0.1mmol) was dissolved in CH3OH (10mL), to which an aqueous solution (5mL) of CdX2 (0.1mmol) was added with stirring. After ca. 30min, the solution was filtered and left to stand under room temperature. Upon slow evaporation of the solvents, colorless block crystals of complexes 1-3 were produced after ca. 10days.

X-ray crystallography

Single crystal X-ray diffraction data for complexes 1-3 were collected on a Bruker APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å) at room temperature. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined anisotropically on F 2 for all non-hydrogen atoms by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXTL software. Hydrogen atoms of the L434  ligand were generated geometrically with assigned isotropic thermal parameters, whereas those of water in 3 cannot be properly located. The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for four complexes are summarized in  . Selected bond distances and angles are listed in  .

<ce:section-title id="st030">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st035">Description of crystal structures</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st040">Structure description of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction study shows that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a 1D chain motif. The asymmetric unit consists of one and a half Cd(II) centers, one <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligand, and three chloride anions (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a). In this structure, the Cd(II) ions adopt different coordination spheres. The half-occupied Cd1, locating at an inversion center of (0,<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0,<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1), is surrounded by a pair of nitrogen donors (N5) from the 4-pyridyl groups of two <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> and four bridging chloride ions, taking an octahedral geometry. The tetrahedral Cd2 center is coordinated by one 4-pyridyl ring (N1) from <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligand and three chloride ions, one of which is terminal and the other two serve as bridging. Thus, three Cd(II) centers (one Cd1 plus two Cd2) are interlinked by a pair of di-chloro-bridges to afford a [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] trinuclear unit (see b), where the neighboring Cd1⋯Cd2 separation is 3.802<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Cd1–Cl–Cd2 angles are 84.3° and 86.1°, respectively. The Cd–Cl bond lengths within the trinuclear unit are in the range of 2.587(3)–3.026(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, being comparable to those observed in the mono-, di-, and tri-chloro-bridging Cd(II) binuclear entities . These adjoining units are extended into a 1D motif by paired μ-<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligands via the 4-pyridyl groups, with the presence of intrachain π–π stacking interactions, with the centroid-to-centroid separations and the dihedral angles of the involved triazolyl/triazolyl and 4-pyridyl/4-pyridyl groups being 3.530/3.860<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 0/11.5°, respectively. The adjacent coordination patterns are distributed in a parallel mode without significant interchain interactions (see c).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Description of crystal structures

Structure description of 1 

Single crystal X-ray diffraction study shows that complex 1 is a 1D chain motif. The asymmetric unit consists of one and a half Cd(II) centers, one L434  ligand, and three chloride anions (see  a). In this structure, the Cd(II) ions adopt different coordination spheres. The half-occupied Cd1, locating at an inversion center of (0,0,1), is surrounded by a pair of nitrogen donors (N5) from the 4-pyridyl groups of two L434  and four bridging chloride ions, taking an octahedral geometry. The tetrahedral Cd2 center is coordinated by one 4-pyridyl ring (N1) from L434  ligand and three chloride ions, one of which is terminal and the other two serve as bridging. Thus, three Cd(II) centers (one Cd1 plus two Cd2) are interlinked by a pair of di-chloro-bridges to afford a [Cd3Cl4] trinuclear unit (see b), where the neighboring Cd1⋯Cd2 separation is 3.802Å, and the Cd1-Cl-Cd2 angles are 84.3° and 86.1°, respectively. The Cd-Cl bond lengths within the trinuclear unit are in the range of 2.587(3)-3.026(3)Å, being comparable to those observed in the mono-, di-, and tri-chloro-bridging Cd(II) binuclear entities . These adjoining units are extended into a 1D motif by paired μ-L434  ligands via the 4-pyridyl groups, with the presence of intrachain π-π stacking interactions, with the centroid-to-centroid separations and the dihedral angles of the involved triazolyl/triazolyl and 4-pyridyl/4-pyridyl groups being 3.530/3.860Å and 0/11.5°, respectively. The adjacent coordination patterns are distributed in a parallel mode without significant interchain interactions (see c).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st045">Structure description of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">When Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> is replaced by Br<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, another 1D coordination polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is achieved, of which the asymmetric unit contains half Cd(II) center, one <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligand, and one bromide ion. The half-occupied Cd(II) ion has a distorted octahedral geometry, provided by four nitrogen atoms from two 3-pyridyl rings (N6) and two 4-pyridyl rings (N5) of four <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligands, as well as paired terminal bromide ions (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a). The Cd–Br bond length is 2.6727(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, being in the normal range for Cd–Br<ce:inf loc="post">terminal</ce:inf> bonds . In this case, the neighboring Cd(II) centers are combined by paired <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligands via the 3-pyridyl and 4-pyridyl groups to construct a [Cd(<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> binuclear unit with the Cd⋯Cd separation of 9.225(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Moreover, such units are extended by sharing the Cd(II) centers to constitute a 1D box-like pattern (see b). Further analysis of the crystal packing shows that such 1D arrays take the parallel stacking mode with some offset, which facilitates the formation of interchain π–π aromatic interactions between the uncoordinated 4-pyridyl rings from neighboring 1D chains (see c). The centroid-to-centroid and face-to-face separations between the 4-pyridyl groups are 3.768 and 3.288<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. As a result, 2D layered supramolecular nets are afforded, which are arranged in a parallel fashion without further weak interaction.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure description of 2 

When Cl- is replaced by Br-, another 1D coordination polymer 2 is achieved, of which the asymmetric unit contains half Cd(II) center, one L434  ligand, and one bromide ion. The half-occupied Cd(II) ion has a distorted octahedral geometry, provided by four nitrogen atoms from two 3-pyridyl rings (N6) and two 4-pyridyl rings (N5) of four L434  ligands, as well as paired terminal bromide ions (see  a). The Cd-Br bond length is 2.6727(3)Å, being in the normal range for Cd-Brterminal bonds . In this case, the neighboring Cd(II) centers are combined by paired L434  ligands via the 3-pyridyl and 4-pyridyl groups to construct a [Cd(L434 )]2 binuclear unit with the Cd⋯Cd separation of 9.225(1)Å. Moreover, such units are extended by sharing the Cd(II) centers to constitute a 1D box-like pattern (see b). Further analysis of the crystal packing shows that such 1D arrays take the parallel stacking mode with some offset, which facilitates the formation of interchain π-π aromatic interactions between the uncoordinated 4-pyridyl rings from neighboring 1D chains (see c). The centroid-to-centroid and face-to-face separations between the 4-pyridyl groups are 3.768 and 3.288Å, respectively. As a result, 2D layered supramolecular nets are afforded, which are arranged in a parallel fashion without further weak interaction.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st050">Structure description of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">By introducing larger I<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions into the assembling system, another 1D polymeric array <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is obtained. There are two crystallographic distinct Cd(II) centers, two <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligands, four iodide ions and two water molecules as ligand in the asymmetric unit (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>a). Cd1 is coordinated by two different 4-pyridyl rings (N5 and N7) from two <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligands, three iodide ions (one terminal and two bridging), and one water molecule as ligand, taking a distorted octahedral sphere. Each Cd2 center is five-coordinated, locating in a nearly ideal square-pyramidal geometry with the <ce:italic>τ</ce:italic> parameter of 0.05 , where one terminal iodide ion, one water molecule as ligand, and two pyridyl nitrogen donors of <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> constitute the basal plane and the other iodide ion occupy the axial position. The deviation of Cd(II) center from the least squares basal plane is 0.7206<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. As shown in b, with the aid of μ-<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligand via its two 4-pyridyl groups, the neighboring Cd1 and Cd2 centers are connected into a 1D chain, and two such chains are further interlinked by di-iodido-bridges to construct a ladder-like array. As a result, the centrosymmetric binuclear unit [CdI]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is formed, with separation of Cd⋯Cd and angle of Cd1–I–Cd1 being 4.395<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 91.1°, respectively. The Cd–I bond lengths in the binuclear unit are in the range of 2.981(2)–3.173(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which are comparable to those found in other di-iodido-bridging Cd(II) binuclear entities . In this 1D motif, face-to-face π–π stacking interactions between the triazolyl rings and between the 4-pyridyl groups are observed, with the centroid-to-centroid separations and the dihedral angles being 3.375/3.921<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 0.12/13.22°, respectively. Of further interests, those 1D arrays are alternately arranged in a vertical fashion along the [1<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0] direction (see c).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure description of 3 

By introducing larger I- ions into the assembling system, another 1D polymeric array 3 is obtained. There are two crystallographic distinct Cd(II) centers, two L434  ligands, four iodide ions and two water molecules as ligand in the asymmetric unit (see  a). Cd1 is coordinated by two different 4-pyridyl rings (N5 and N7) from two L434  ligands, three iodide ions (one terminal and two bridging), and one water molecule as ligand, taking a distorted octahedral sphere. Each Cd2 center is five-coordinated, locating in a nearly ideal square-pyramidal geometry with the τ parameter of 0.05 , where one terminal iodide ion, one water molecule as ligand, and two pyridyl nitrogen donors of L434  constitute the basal plane and the other iodide ion occupy the axial position. The deviation of Cd(II) center from the least squares basal plane is 0.7206Å. As shown in b, with the aid of μ-L434  ligand via its two 4-pyridyl groups, the neighboring Cd1 and Cd2 centers are connected into a 1D chain, and two such chains are further interlinked by di-iodido-bridges to construct a ladder-like array. As a result, the centrosymmetric binuclear unit [CdI]2 is formed, with separation of Cd⋯Cd and angle of Cd1-I-Cd1 being 4.395Å and 91.1°, respectively. The Cd-I bond lengths in the binuclear unit are in the range of 2.981(2)-3.173(2)Å, which are comparable to those found in other di-iodido-bridging Cd(II) binuclear entities . In this 1D motif, face-to-face π-π stacking interactions between the triazolyl rings and between the 4-pyridyl groups are observed, with the centroid-to-centroid separations and the dihedral angles being 3.375/3.921Å and 0.12/13.22°, respectively. Of further interests, those 1D arrays are alternately arranged in a vertical fashion along the [100] direction (see c).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st055">Structural comparision of complexes</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">As stated above, halide ions are found to regulate the various 1D coordination polymers during assembling with Cd(II) and <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligand (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). In complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligands adopt the (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, μ) binding fashion to serve as the similar linear spacer by use of two 4-pyridyl rings. For <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligand also displays the (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, μ) coordination mode, but presents a V-angled linker by use of 3-pyridyl and 4-pyridyl rings. On the other hand, by varying the halide anions, distinct [Cd<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>X<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>] subunits can be observed in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The trinuclear unit [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> results from a pair of di-chloro-bridges, and for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, all the bromide anions are in the terminal binding fashion. In <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, with the aid of di-iodido-bridges, binuclear subunit Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> can be generated. Of further interest, the change of halide ions in these complexes will also be responsible for their different fluorescent intensities.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structural comparision of complexes

As stated above, halide ions are found to regulate the various 1D coordination polymers during assembling with Cd(II) and L434  ligand (see  ). In complexes 1 and 3, L434  ligands adopt the (η2, μ) binding fashion to serve as the similar linear spacer by use of two 4-pyridyl rings. For 2, L434  ligand also displays the (η2, μ) coordination mode, but presents a V-angled linker by use of 3-pyridyl and 4-pyridyl rings. On the other hand, by varying the halide anions, distinct [Cd n X m ] subunits can be observed in 1-3. The trinuclear unit [Cd3Cl4] in 1 results from a pair of di-chloro-bridges, and for 2, all the bromide anions are in the terminal binding fashion. In 3, with the aid of di-iodido-bridges, binuclear subunit Cd2I2 can be generated. Of further interest, the change of halide ions in these complexes will also be responsible for their different fluorescent intensities.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st060">Photoluminescence properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Coordination polymers involving d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal centers and aromatic organic spacers have current been a promising class of candidates for functional crystalline materials with good photoluminescent properties . Thus, solid-state emission spectra of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and the free <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligand were studied at ambient conditions, as depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>. Excitation of the microcrystalline samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> at 280<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm leads to visible fluorescence emissions with the peak maxima occurring at 392<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 390<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and 392<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The fluorescent spectrum of the free <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> displays the maximum emission peak at 354<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>320<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm). The obvious red shift of the maximum emissions of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> compared with that of <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligand can be attributed to the coordination interactions of Cd(II) centers with <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">434</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligands. Significantly, complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> show different emission intensities, which should be mainly caused by the halide anions therein as well as the effect of water molecule as ligand in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence properties

Coordination polymers involving d10 metal centers and aromatic organic spacers have current been a promising class of candidates for functional crystalline materials with good photoluminescent properties . Thus, solid-state emission spectra of complexes 1-3 and the free L434  ligand were studied at ambient conditions, as depicted in  . Excitation of the microcrystalline samples of 1-3 at 280nm leads to visible fluorescence emissions with the peak maxima occurring at 392nm for 1, 390nm for 2, and 392nm for 3. The fluorescent spectrum of the free L434  displays the maximum emission peak at 354nm (λ ex =320nm). The obvious red shift of the maximum emissions of 1-3 compared with that of L434  ligand can be attributed to the coordination interactions of Cd(II) centers with L434  ligands. Significantly, complexes 1-3 show different emission intensities, which should be mainly caused by the halide anions therein as well as the effect of water molecule as ligand in 3.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st065">Thermal study</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Thermal stability of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was studied by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>). For complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the coordination patterns are solvent-free and the TG traces reveal a relatively higher thermal stability (both stable up to ca. 345<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C). Decomposition supervenes with several different and consecutive steps of weight loss upon further heating, which does not stop at ca. 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The TGA curve of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> shows the first loss of 2.33% in the range of 78–248<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponding to the removal of two coordinated water molecules. Pyrolysis of the residual sample is observed upon heating to 407<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C with a very sharp weight lose, which does not end until 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal study

Thermal stability of complexes 1-3 was studied by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments (see  ). For complexes 1 and 2, the coordination patterns are solvent-free and the TG traces reveal a relatively higher thermal stability (both stable up to ca. 345°C). Decomposition supervenes with several different and consecutive steps of weight loss upon further heating, which does not stop at ca. 800°C. The TGA curve of 3 shows the first loss of 2.33% in the range of 78-248°C, corresponding to the removal of two coordinated water molecules. Pyrolysis of the residual sample is observed upon heating to 407°C with a very sharp weight lose, which does not end until 800°C.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st070">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">In conclusion, three coordination polymers assembled from a novel tripyridyltriazole tecton and Cd(II) halides are presented, which display distinct 1D polymeric coordination motifs and supramolecular lattices with aromatic stacking interactions. This result demonstrates that the halide ions can remarkably influence the structures and properties of these crystalline solids, which will promote us to further systematically explore such interesting coordination assembled systems.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, three coordination polymers assembled from a novel tripyridyltriazole tecton and Cd(II) halides are presented, which display distinct 1D polymeric coordination motifs and supramolecular lattices with aromatic stacking interactions. This result demonstrates that the halide ions can remarkably influence the structures and properties of these crystalline solids, which will promote us to further systematically explore such interesting coordination assembled systems.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence properties

Coordination polymers involving d10 metal centers and aromatic organic spacers have current been a promising class of candidates for functional crystalline materials with good photoluminescent properties . Thus, solid-state emission spectra of complexes 1-3 and the free L434  ligand were studied at ambient conditions, as depicted in  . Excitation of the microcrystalline samples of 1-3 at 280nm leads to visible fluorescence emissions with the peak maxima occurring at 392nm for 1, 390nm for 2, and 392nm for 3. The fluorescent spectrum of the free L434  displays the maximum emission peak at 354nm (λ ex =320nm). The obvious red shift of the maximum emissions of 1-3 compared with that of L434  ligand can be attributed to the coordination interactions of Cd(II) centers with L434  ligands. Significantly, complexes 1-3 show different emission intensities, which should be mainly caused by the halide anions therein as well as the effect of water molecule as ligand in 3.

Thermal study

Thermal stability of complexes 1-3 was studied by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments (see  ). For complexes 1 and 2, the coordination patterns are solvent-free and the TG traces reveal a relatively higher thermal stability (both stable up to ca. 345°C). Decomposition supervenes with several different and consecutive steps of weight loss upon further heating, which does not stop at ca. 800°C. The TGA curve of 3 shows the first loss of 2.33% in the range of 78-248°C, corresponding to the removal of two coordinated water molecules. Pyrolysis of the residual sample is observed upon heating to 407°C with a very sharp weight lose, which does not end until 800°C.

decomposition temperature.type: removal of two coordinated water molecules

<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0005">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">(a) Portion view of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with atom labeling of the asymmetric unit and coordination environments of Cd(II) centers (symmetry codes: A<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1; B<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, <ce:italic>z<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1; C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:italic>x<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, −<ce:italic>y<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>1, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>). (b) The 1D coordination motif of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The aromatic π–π stacking interactions are shown as green dashed lines. (c) View of the parallel stacking mode of the 1D arrays in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.).</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) Portion view of 1 with atom labeling of the asymmetric unit and coordination environments of Cd(II) centers (symmetry codes: A=-x, -y, -z +1; B= x -1, y -1, z +1; C=-x +1, -y+ 1, -z). (b) The 1D coordination motif of 1. The aromatic π-π stacking interactions are shown as green dashed lines. (c) View of the parallel stacking mode of the 1D arrays in 1. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.).

cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  (a) Portion view of 2 with atom labeling of the asymmetric unit and coordination environment of Cd(II) center (symmetry codes: A=-x +1, -y+ 1, -z +1; B=-x +2, -y+ 2, -z +1; C= x -1, y -1, z). (b) The 1D coordination motif of 2. (c) 2D supramolecular layers supported by aromatic stacking interactions (green dashed lines) in 2, which are arranged in the parallel fashion. The aromatic π-π stacking interactions are shown as green dashed lines. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.).
